lead: My main goal for 2014 at The Coder Factory, is to bring coding into the mainstream. I want people to see that coding is not just for geeks and nerds, everyone can learn to code and build apps that make their lives better.
content:
My vision is for kids, grannies, hipsters, lawyers, accountants, doctors, tradies and chefs to be coding. There are so many possibilities out there where having the power to code, can improve your work and your life forever.

The year that was

The last year has been speeding us towards this time in history. Hardly a day goes by that I don't hear coding being talked about it the press or on tv.

2013 saw a homeless man learning to code and releasing apps. We marvelled at a 12 year old kid presenting a TED talk about his apps on the app store.

Just a few weeks ago, Code.org, the American organisation doing a great job of pushing the 'coding in schools' agenda, ran the successful Hour of Code. Over 20 million kids had a go at coding, more than the total number of kids to ever learn computer science before that week.

In November, I spoke at Ignite Sydney, a short format talk event. My chosen topic, "Teach the world to code" must have inspired President Obama because 3 days after the video of my talk was released on Youtube, Obama uploaded a speech encouraging all Americans to learn to code. :)

Strategy for 2014

To achieve my goal and make coding mainstream, I am making some plans and devising a strategy.

Javascript courses

To kick off, The Coder Factory is offering Australia's first Angular.js course. If you are a Rails developer (or other MVC framework developer) looking to take your web applications to the next level, come and learn Angular.

Javascript MVC frameworks are the future of front end web development. You have to be living with your head in a bag if you haven't noticed the increasing buzz and demand for Javascript skills.

Summer of Code

I will be announcing more Coder Factory initiatives every week during this #summerofcode. Look out, it's going to be a huge year for coding!

Enjoy the rest of your holidays and #learntocode!

title: Why Learning in Classrooms is better than online resources. Part 2.
lead: In Part 2 of this series, this will hopefully improve the correlation between Classroom learning and Online learning and will hopefully give you a better perspective on what is the right choice for your success.
content:
Hey rad viewers ☺ and welcome to others that may have never seen this blog before, I will be continuing the 2-part series on why learning in classrooms is better than online resources when building your own apps and businesses. You are now also part of the rad community ☺

As previously mentioned in part 1 of this blog post, being a cofounder of The Coder Factory gives me the opportunity to meet aspiring entrepreneurs who have tried to learn code online and build their own startups and businesses without really knowing what the best program is to learn, what direction and focus they should take in terms of web design, what is the best marketing tactics in terms of functionality and design to gain the most traction, etc.… etc.… The list is endless. There are numerous factors to consider that most entrepreneurs just simply don’t know about.

As I explained in part 1, “Whatever your purposes, for a career opportunity or running your business, learning in the classroom, such as a coding school, is much more effective in gaining employment and increasing your chances of a successful business venture or tech startup.”

Coding sounds like a daunting task (and trust me, at first I had exactly the same feeling), but learning a little code will not only help you in discovery and creativity, but help you have more power and control over your business to gain higher customer acquisition.

You guys should read this article (a little old I know, but serves the same core meaning) by Venture Beat interviewing the Co-Founder and CEO of CodeAcademy, Zach Sims. It’s a skill and investment that would never be regretted, hence why I’m so passionate in letting people know and that learning in a classroom environment is a fun experience.

Here are the other 2 reasons why Learning in classrooms is better than online resources;

3. Networking

From my experience thus far, learning in a classroom has already helped me gain quite a few useful contacts for my start-up. Networking is critical and is the catalyst for success.

When enrolling for any start-up bootcamps or coding classes, you will instantly have your networking skills put to the test. You will mix with people who have similar ambitions and goals that they want to achieve emotionally, financially and most importantly, passionately. The ability to network is an art and will make you become more proficient with your business and programmers also increasing their skills. Two perfect examples are Mark Collins, a former student of The Coder Factory, has been accepted in the Incubator program at the University of Sydney for his start-up, Viber (Exciting blog post coming very soon on Mark as well ☺).

Another recent example is Phil Simmonds being hired by Black Citrus. The perfect way to start networking is by going to workshops and learning in classrooms where it’s not just going there to work, but you make great friends too. This is not possible when learning online. Yes, it costs money, sure thing, but I guarantee it is the best investment you will ever make, if you want to be highly successful that is (I’m sure you do ☺).

4. Fast-paced learning and working on project while learning at the same time.

Here is the final reason why I chose to be a coding student and do it in a classroom instead of learning online. It’s so much DAMN FASTER. I’ve picked up things where I learned it on CodeAcademy, like CSS and HTML, and did it within 2 lessons, where learning it online took me a couple of weeks.

Most of you guys are probably now thinking, “Ha! Well maybe your just not to switched on aren’t you?”. I’m not suggesting that I’m witty either, but trust me, I’m quite switched on. But it goes back to my first reason back in Part 1… motivation. Lack of motivation and socialising is the huge reason it took me a couple of weeks to learn.

It was cool building a site and learning basic web design, and I encourage people to take that initial step to see how coding works, but just imagine the possibilities of building a whole project in only a handful of weeks, in a fun learning environment whilst networking at the same time (that it will eventually become subliminal to you). If I were you, learning in the classroom is the best option.

Let me know what you rad viewers think of these reasons. I would love to hear maybe why you might disagree or maybe agree on some points and not others. Also, please if anyone can think of other reasons I would like to hear them as well.

Until next time, Peace ☺

title: Student interview - Sylvain Aimoz
lead: Sylvain is one of our most advanced students. He is a genuine geek who is totally into game development. Sylvain took our advanced course as well as our Angular.JS course and was kind enough to tell us a little bit about his experience.
content:
Hi Sylvain, thank you for taking the time to tell the community about your experience! Could you tell us a bit about yourself?

I’m just a geek that had the “chance” to get a computer quite late compared to my friends when I was a kid (yeah 16yo, not such a kid anymore right?)... I used to change the components, install, re-install, re-re-install windows because something went wrong while patching games and updating dodgy drivers back in the old era of the late 90’s.. and then I studied electronics and after that, network management because I thought I would enjoy it.

You took our Advanced Web App Developer Deluxe program, how did you find it and have you enjoyed the experience?

It was a pretty cool experience, lots to learn, sometimes obvious, sometimes it left me clueless, but that’s what happen when you’re learning! 

At the Coder Factory, we believe Coding is a necessary skill in the 21st Century. What are your thoughts on this statement?

Well, definitely! Computers are not only on the boss’s desk anymore… They’re in your pockets 24/7! Obviously there’s a difference between using them and developing software for them, but it would be like having car and not knowing what’s that red light on the dashboard means.. And yes, this red light means the handbrake is still on.. It’s a silly comparison, but the more you know about your tools, the more you can achieve.

It’s safe to say you’re now quite familiar with coding, do you think you will transverse these skills in creating your own tech startup and enhance your innovative possibilities in the digital landscape?

I have been coding for quite a while, but at an amateur level, using tools and tweaking a few things in hexadecimal and stuff like that but it has always been quite obscure, and to be honest it will still be for a while.. coding can be compared to talking, you create sounds and say words, but remember how much time it took to learn your native language? Yep, let’s say 10 years to be “OK”, and that’s just the beginning!Same for coding, you use a, or should I say, many languages at the same time and to be fluent in coding, you need to spend time practicing and learning more. You need to learn the logic, the syntax and the vocabulary, which are different in assembler, C, javascript, HTML and that’s just the tip of the iceberg…I’ve done a few websites back in the days, when it was only just few static webpages, and I was using the few concept that I knew to help me doing IT and “playing” with videogames, and by playing I mean doing maps, and what we would call mods nowadays.. And after few years discovering software like Blender and lately Unity3D, I tried to develop one by myself, and that’s mainly why I decided to do that small course, just to give me more insights of what was happening, and let me tell you, the more you know, the less you know!

You have also taken our inaugural AngularJs class. How did you find it and will you use AngularJs in future projects?

I tend to say, never say never, and AngularJS is pretty awesome, with many cutting-edge concepts that will definitely push web-programming to something always more dynamic, evolving and secure, but what I’m working on at the moment would not work with angularJS as it’s mainly “native”, but as I make it available online.. you never know, at some point maybe the technologies will get close enough to use them together.

If you have to give any advice on people interested in learning coding and web app development, what would you say?

You can do it online, read books etc.. but if you can do the class at the coder factory, you will have a better and quicker understanding of what’s going on. It’s pretty cheap when you think to the time you will save at the start and straight to the point, get the basics and then pick tips online, like when you’re passing your driver’s licence, learn to drive and then go on a road trip!

Thank you for your time Sylvain!

title: Top 8 Ruby on Rails Blogs
lead: “Ruby on Rails is a breakthrough in lowering the barriers of entry to programming. Powerful web applications that formerly might have taken weeks or months to develop can be produced in a matter of days.”– Tim O’Reilly, Founder of O’Reilly Media
content:
When Ruby on rails was first initially released back on 13 December 2005, over the years it has become one of the most popular programming frameworks in the world. It has produced some of the world’s most famous and influential startups and platforms that exist today.

Related Reading: Top 15 Sites built with Ruby on Rails

There will always be a debate whether or not Ruby on Rails is the best programming language and framework to use, with the likes of other popular languages such as Django and Node.js – however, Ruby on Rails has an amazing community of resources to help you out on your journey, whether starting out or an experienced programmer wanting to learn more or improve your skills with Ruby on Rails. 

In this blog post, we're going to highlight the Top 8 Best Ruby on rails blogs on the web.

1. Riding Rails

Riding Rails is the official blog for Ruby on Rails from the rubyonrails.org team. They will keep you up to date with everything Ruby on Rails including news and tips on bugs/patches, screencasts, documentation (guides, APIs, books), and community - and, of course, not to mention the place to download and kick start your Ruby on Rails adventure. Their blog with has all the latest and features about Ruby on Rails and is regularly updated with credible information, which will keep you on track.

 

2. Ruby Inside

Ruby Inside has been one of the oldest Ruby blogs out there and has been there nearly since day one of Ruby on rails being released. Not only do they keep you up to date with the best news and tutorials, they are committed to their email newsletter called Ruby Weekly. It is agreat resource to automatically keep you up to date with the latest Ruby on rails news straight to your inbox.

 

3. Rails Casts

 

If you’re not the type of person who just likes to read text and follow, then Rails Casts is the perfect Podcast and Screencasts resource for you. They have an amazing array of tutorials and news about Ruby on Rails on their site and RSS feeds.

Despite being an amazing resource, it isn’t free. For a $9 a month fee, you can get everything from every old episode to an extra advanced episode each week. If you want to supercharge your Ruby on Rails learning and experience, then it might be worth paying the small fee. 

 

4. The Ruby Toolbox

The Ruby Toolbox is a great resource catalogue of Ruby on Rails Plug-ins, gems, tools, news and announcements through their blog with an extensive array of categories of valuable information for Rubyists.

They also have an amazing Ruby Project category from A-Z, which is the perfect place for any Advanced Rails developer to take a sneak peak.

 

5. Ruby Flow

Ruby Flow is a Ruby programming community Link blog which is quickly growing in numbers of users and is consistently used everyday where people share their gems, tips, news, podcasts, support, tutorials and other helpful resources for beginners looking to get an edge or create that spark for their app.

It is also the perfect place for Ruby programmers to ask questions to other fellow programmers – similar to Stack Overflow but for Ruby on Rails. I think this community will grow nicely over time.

 

6. Rails App Project

The team at RailsApp Project is a wonderful service teaching everything about Ruby on Rails from Beginner to more experienced and Advanced Ruby on Rails developers. They do have various packages to access their extensive online resources starting from $19 a month, which includes their amazing blog, which is updated regularly. If you have the money and want to further enhance your experience, it is a worthy purchase.  

 

7. Planet Ruby on Rails

 

Planet Ruby on Rails is a fantastic blog to keep up with everything Ruby from expert voices. What is so great about Planet Ruby on Rails is there extensive amount of interview of real programmers and people involved in the Rails community. They provide great insights into some experiences of Ruby on Rails application developers as well as provide extensive knowledge on the latest gems and tutorials for a better rails app experience.

They even describe themselves in this awesome slogan:

has_many :blogs , :through => :feeds

 

8. A Fresh Cup

With a name that finally doesn’t include the words either ‘Ruby’ or ‘Rails’, it’s a personal blog by Software and Rails developer Mike Gunderloy where he expresses his Ruby on rails experience and whatever interests him in the development world. If you like his stuff, he is also available for consulting – just drop him a line.

 

Thanks for reading this blog  - If there are other important Ruby on Rails blogs that we have missed out and deserve attention, make sure to comment below and let me know. Would love to check it out.

title: Student interview - Jessa Boanas-Dewes
lead: Jessa is the founder and director of Toot Sweet. She has taken our Foundation Programme and we are very happy that she agreed to tell us about her experience.
content:
Thanks for agreeing to do this Interview with us Jessa. Before we ask you further questions, do you mind telling us about your career background and your business Toot Sweet?

Sure! I founded Toot Sweet over six years ago and now we have teams in Australia and New Zealand. Toot Sweet specialises in technical and business writing for bids and tenders – particularly for multi-million and multi-billion dollar civil construction projects in Australia. We mainly work with engineers to ‘translate’ their technical knowledge and expertise, into clear, concise and easy-to-read text, so that their clients can easily understand the solutions and benefits they propose. My career background is in publishing (my favourite was working at Lonely Planet!), sustainable development, marketing and analysis. 

Great to hear about your business Toot Sweet, where do you plan on taking the company in terms of growth?

Toot Sweet has grown organically in a really great way – we have a great culture and really amazing writers, so I’m very conscious of keeping that and enhancing it as we grow. The plan is to continue to grow team sizes and add teams in more cities. The challenge is now to make sure our systems are ready for the next stage of growth! Which is why I became interested in learning about the potential of coding. 

Congratulations on completing your first course with coderfactory. What was the experience like?

I loved coming to class and seeing how quickly you can create apps, websites and systems that are exactly what your business or client needs. The environment was incredibly friendly and the teachers were fun and super helpful. 

What can you tell us about what you built?

Ahhh, not much yet – but it gave me a great grounding in what is possible, which is what I wanted!

Tell us why you wanted to learn to build an app and what you hope to get out of it.

I wanted to get an idea of what sort of back end systems I could build (or have someone build for me) so that I can strengthen and build my business. 

What do you think about learning Technology and coding and has it has any impact on the way you look at business? Has it generated more thoughts on how to implement better Technological decisions?

I think coding is a great thing to learn – it’s definitley impacted the way I look at business. I feel that my creativity and ideas have increased now that I have a better idea of what is possible. 

What did you enjoy most about studying at coderfactory?

Peter’s sense of humour!

Are you satisfied that you learned code? Did you find it difficult?

I didn’t find it difficult at all. 

Do you believe coding is just for “geeks” or “nerds”?

Well, I think I am a nerd! But no of course not, I think it’s for everyone. It’s an incredibly powerful tool. 

What would you say to other people interested in learning to code?

I’d say get in to it! 

In one sentence, how would you describe coderfactory?

A great, open and forward-thinking factory of fabulous coders!
